ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In this class, we learned about the history of music in the West and how the origins of popular music traveled and formed pop music today. In the New Wave section of the class, there was much more focus on the instruments and music itself, while in the K-pop section of the class, we looked at the imagery and presentation of pop music.
knowledge about ska, reggae, british new wave, k-pop, and the government's involvement

This class is one of my favorite classes I have tacked so far. In class discussions are so insightful and you really gain a comprehensive understanding of multiple genres across different countries and decades.

We learned about the history of New Wave, spanning from the 1960s to 1980s in the first half of the semester. In the second half of the semester, we learned about the history of K-Pop, spanning from the 1980s to now. Along the way, we learned about New Wave's influence on racial and social dynamics of its time period, and its consequent influence on K-Pop.
This course was amazing!!! Professor Kao creates such a wonderful environment to learn, coming from someone who did not was any knowledge of either genre.
How to identify new wave music, the historical background behind new wave and kpop
I learned more about music and how to analyze music. I learned more about music industries and how they work, as well as how to look at music from a sociological lens.
histories and connections between different genres of music, learned lots about the k-pop industry and how it functions

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Interesting material, fun assignments, and Professor Kao! Professor Kao is the best professor I have had at Yale so far! She is very understanding and will always make time to talk to her students if they need any help at all (or just want to talk!) 
Weaknesses: None! However, if you take this class because of just New Wave or just K-pop, you will find the other half of the class quite boring compared to the section of the class that is about the music you like! So, be open-minded.

strengths: fun class if you're interested in these music topics, easy to understand, super engaging
weaknesses: power points were sometimes boring

Strengths: Professor Kao! She is very knowledgeable about the history of both New Wave and K-Pop, and being an ER&M and Sociology professor allows her to go more in-depth on the racial and social dynamics of the time. The class promotes collaboration, and we (classmates) got really close by the end of the semester! Professor Kao created a fun environment and encouraged us to share our thoughts and opinions. The guest speakers were also all lovely and it was nice to hear from people who lived through what we learned in class. 
Weaknesses: None, really! The only "complaint" I would have is that because the material is relatively new (the material being New Wave and K-Pop and how they're connected), there aren't many academic writings, which makes it difficult to use multiple sources other than the ones we read in class for our final papers.
Loved the set up

Strength: lots of content on music but is very engaging to someone that doesnt know a lot 

Weakness: doesnt cover enough on kpop towards the end

There are literally no weaknesses in this course. Professor Kao is so engaging and understanding and she is truly passionate about this topic. This was the first seminar class where I wasn't afraid to speak at all!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!! This class is so fun and a nice change of pace from other classes. Professor Kao always has the best lectures and clips to show during class so attending class is always a nice break from the usual grind.
yes! if you like the music genres or are just interested in learning about new music, this is definitely for you. our weekly work consists of listening/watching playlists and readings.
Yes, one of my favorite courses I have tacked. Assignments are super engaging and fun. Im class topic are always fascinating and very interesting!

Yes! 100%! If you are a fan of either New Wave or K-Pop music, or even just music in general, then you will definitely like this class! It's not just a music history class, as we really do learn about how "race, place, and gender" influenced New Wave and K-Pop music. Professor Kao is an incredibly nice professor that will definitely make your first year much brighter!
Yes. Professor Kao is a great professor who truly cares about her students and is passionate about the subject being taught.
Yes take it!
Yes, it's a lot of fun, and the environment, especially as a first-year, encourages academic conversation between the professor and classmates without any feelings of pressure.
Yes, especially someone that enjoys music or kpop specifically

YESYESYES!!! A thousand times yes especially if you like british new wave and k-pop! This was definately my favorite class of my fist year and I'm so glad I got to take it. The essays aren't much and the playlists don't even feel like homework if you listen to them with someone else and jam along together!

extras.title: ER&M 081 01/MUSI 081 01/SOCY 081 01 - Race in New Wave & K-Pop
